      ---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Report description<span class="line"><!---->### Report description<!----></span><br><br><br>v8/Turbofan: Invalid rotate-right optimization + Typer hardening bypass<span class="line"><!---->v8/Turbofan: Invalid rotate-right optimization + Typer hardening bypass<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Bug location<span class="line"><!---->### Bug location<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<span class="line"><!---->#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<!----></span><br><br>Google Chrome<span class="line"><!---->Google Chrome<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The problem<span class="line"><!---->### The problem<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Tested on:<span class="line"><!---->Tested on:<!----></span><br>==========<span class="line"><!---->==========<!----></span><br><br> - Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux (other platforms affected too)<span class="line"><!----> - Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux (other platforms affected too)<!----></span><br> - v8/d8 on current main branch on Linux<span class="line"><!----> - v8/d8 on current main branch on Linux<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br>Test case:<span class="line"><!---->Test case:<!----></span><br>==========<span class="line"><!---->==========<!----></span><br><br>Execute the following snippet in Chrome's Javascript console or d8:<span class="line"><!---->Execute the following snippet in Chrome's Javascript console or d8:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>function foo(a,b) {<span class="line"><!---->function foo(a,b) {<!----></span><br>    a = a|0;<span class="line"><!---->    a = a|0;<!----></span><br>    b = b|0;<span class="line"><!---->    b = b|0;<!----></span><br>    return (a >>> b) ^ (a << (32-b));<span class="line"><!---->    return (a &gt;&gt;&gt; b) ^ (a &lt;&lt; (32-b));<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>console.log(foo(1, 0));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(foo(1, 0));<!----></span><br>for (var i = 0; i < 3e5; i++) foo(1, 0);<span class="line"><!---->for (var i = 0; i &lt; 3e5; i++) foo(1, 0);<!----></span><br>console.log(foo(1, 0));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(foo(1, 0));<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>The expected behavior would be to print "0" twice; instead "0" and "1" are printed.<span class="line"><!---->The expected behavior would be to print "0" twice; instead "0" and "1" are printed.<!----></span><br>I will show below how this can be used to construct mis-typed values, and achieve arbitrary code execution in the context of v8/Chrome's Renderer process using a typer hardening bypass.<span class="line"><!---->I will show below how this can be used to construct mis-typed values, and achieve arbitrary code execution in the context of v8/Chrome's Renderer process using a typer hardening bypass.<!----></span><br><br><br>Root Cause:<span class="line"><!---->Root Cause:<!----></span><br>===========<span class="line"><!---->===========<!----></span><br><br>The relevant optimization is `MachineOperatorReducer::TryMatchWord32Ror()`, around line 1838 of v8's `src/compiler/machine-operator-reducer.cc`:<span class="line"><!---->The relevant optimization is `MachineOperatorReducer::TryMatchWord32Ror()`, around line 1838 of v8's `src/compiler/machine-operator-reducer.cc`:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Reduction MachineOperatorReducer::TryMatchWord32Ror(Node* node) {<span class="line"><!---->Reduction MachineOperatorReducer::TryMatchWord32Ror(Node* node) {<!----></span><br>  DCHECK(IrOpcode::kWord32Or == node->opcode() ||<span class="line"><!---->  DCHECK(IrOpcode::kWord32Or == node-&gt;opcode() ||<!----></span><br>         IrOpcode::kWord32Xor == node->opcode());<span class="line"><!---->         IrOpcode::kWord32Xor == node-&gt;opcode());<!----></span><br>  Int32BinopMatcher m(node);<span class="line"><!---->  Int32BinopMatcher m(node);<!----></span><br>  Node* shl = nullptr;<span class="line"><!---->  Node* shl = nullptr;<!----></span><br>  Node* shr = nullptr;<span class="line"><!---->  Node* shr = nullptr;<!----></span><br>  // Recognize rotation, we are matching:<span class="line"><!---->  // Recognize rotation, we are matching:<!----></span><br>  //  * x << y | x >>> (32 - y) => x ror (32 - y), i.e  x rol y<span class="line"><!---->  //  * x &lt;&lt; y | x &gt;&gt;&gt; (32 - y) =&gt; x ror (32 - y), i.e  x rol y<!----></span><br>  //  * x << (32 - y) | x >>> y => x ror y<span class="line"><!---->  //  * x &lt;&lt; (32 - y) | x &gt;&gt;&gt; y =&gt; x ror y<!----></span><br>  //  * x << y ^ x >>> (32 - y) => x ror (32 - y), i.e. x rol y<span class="line"><!---->  //  * x &lt;&lt; y ^ x &gt;&gt;&gt; (32 - y) =&gt; x ror (32 - y), i.e. x rol y<!----></span><br>  //  * x << (32 - y) ^ x >>> y => x ror y<span class="line"><!---->  //  * x &lt;&lt; (32 - y) ^ x &gt;&gt;&gt; y =&gt; x ror y<!----></span><br>  // as well as their commuted form.<span class="line"><!---->  // as well as their commuted form.<!----></span><br>  ...<span class="line"><!---->  ...<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Consider the last two reductions with the case `y = 0` (or more generally, `y` divisible by 32).<span class="line"><!---->Consider the last two reductions with the case `y = 0` (or more generally, `y` divisible by 32).<!----></span><br>In this case, both left and right shift are by an amount divisible by 32; but as shift amounts are truncated to their last 5 bits this is equivalent to no shift occuring at all, so the left-hand side actually reduces to `x ^ x = 0`.<span class="line"><!---->In this case, both left and right shift are by an amount divisible by 32; but as shift amounts are truncated to their last 5 bits this is equivalent to no shift occuring at all, so the left-hand side actually reduces to `x ^ x = 0`.<!----></span><br>However, the right-hand side reduces to `x ror 0 = x` (again, rotation amounts divisible by 32 are equivalent to 0), which is wrong for non-zero values of `x`.<span class="line"><!---->However, the right-hand side reduces to `x ror 0 = x` (again, rotation amounts divisible by 32 are equivalent to 0), which is wrong for non-zero values of `x`.<!----></span><br><br>Fix:<span class="line"><!---->Fix:<!----></span><br>====<span class="line"><!---->====<!----></span><br><br>The easiest fix would be to disallow the reduction for the Word32Xor operator.<span class="line"><!---->The easiest fix would be to disallow the reduction for the Word32Xor operator.<!----></span><br>However, the optimization can still be performed for the case where `y` and `32 - y` are constants and known to be non-zero (modulo 32).<span class="line"><!---->However, the optimization can still be performed for the case where `y` and `32 - y` are constants and known to be non-zero (modulo 32).<!----></span><br>It's of course enough to check this for `y`.<span class="line"><!---->It's of course enough to check this for `y`.<!----></span><br>A suggested patch is attached as `machine-operator-reducer.cc.patch`.<span class="line"><!---->A suggested patch is attached as `machine-operator-reducer.cc.patch`.<!----></span><br>Optimizing the case of y being constant 0 to `0` does not seem to make sense, as this should already be handled by the existing reductions for shifts and xor.<span class="line"><!---->Optimizing the case of y being constant 0 to `0` does not seem to make sense, as this should already be handled by the existing reductions for shifts and xor.<!----></span><br><br>Note also that the Word32Or-case is unaffected by the bug, as `x << 0 | x >>> 32` is equal to `x | x = x`, which matches `ror(x, 0)`.<span class="line"><!---->Note also that the Word32Or-case is unaffected by the bug, as `x &lt;&lt; 0 | x &gt;&gt;&gt; 32` is equal to `x | x = x`, which matches `ror(x, 0)`.<!----></span><br><br>Exploiting the bug:<span class="line"><!---->Exploiting the bug:<!----></span><br>===================<span class="line"><!---->===================<!----></span><br><br>The rest of this write-up will describe how exactly the bug was triggered in a way that causes a type confusion, and how this type confusion can be leveraged into arbitrary code exeuction using a new typer-hardening bypass.<span class="line"><!---->The rest of this write-up will describe how exactly the bug was triggered in a way that causes a type confusion, and how this type confusion can be leveraged into arbitrary code exeuction using a new typer-hardening bypass.<!----></span><br>A full exploit that executes a customizable shellcode (in the example, for Linux x64) is attached as `ror_rce.js`.<span class="line"><!---->A full exploit that executes a customizable shellcode (in the example, for Linux x64) is attached as `ror_rce.js`.<!----></span><br>It can either be run with a current version of `d8` or embedded into a html file openened with `chrome --no-sandbox` (however the example shellcode has no observable effect when run in Chrome's renderer; there doesn't seem to be an easy portable way to pop a calc on Linux :( ).<span class="line"><!---->It can either be run with a current version of `d8` or embedded into a html file openened with `chrome --no-sandbox` (however the example shellcode has no observable effect when run in Chrome's renderer; there doesn't seem to be an easy portable way to pop a calc on Linux :( ).<!----></span><br><br>To trigger the type confusion in the first place, some further primitives are needed that are now described.<span class="line"><!---->To trigger the type confusion in the first place, some further primitives are needed that are now described.<!----></span><br><br>Typer-opaque constants<span class="line"><!---->Typer-opaque constants<!----></span><br>----------------------<span class="line"><!---->----------------------<!----></span><br><br>It is useful to have values that are unknown to the Typer-phase, but that can be fully reduced to constants during later phases like EarlyOptimization, where `MachineOperatorReducer` is first run.<span class="line"><!---->It is useful to have values that are unknown to the Typer-phase, but that can be fully reduced to constants during later phases like EarlyOptimization, where `MachineOperatorReducer` is first run.<!----></span><br>This can be used to introduce uncertainty into types where needed to prevent e.g. constant folding.<span class="line"><!---->This can be used to introduce uncertainty into types where needed to prevent e.g. constant folding.<!----></span><br>This primitive can be obtained using the LoadElimination-phase: We use a local object `o` to hold a constant `c0` equal to zero; whenever we load this constant the typer can speculate that this is a number, but cannot reason about its exact value.<span class="line"><!---->This primitive can be obtained using the LoadElimination-phase: We use a local object `o` to hold a constant `c0` equal to zero; whenever we load this constant the typer can speculate that this is a number, but cannot reason about its exact value.<!----></span><br><br>During LoadElimination, this is replaced by a constant `0` node, enabling further optimizations.<span class="line"><!---->During LoadElimination, this is replaced by a constant `0` node, enabling further optimizations.<!----></span><br>Note: For unknown reasons, the LoadElimination only seems to work properly when causing the function's optimization with a loop instead of the "%PrepareFunctionForOptimization"/"%OptimizeFunctionOnNextCall" intrinsics.<span class="line"><!---->Note: For unknown reasons, the LoadElimination only seems to work properly when causing the function's optimization with a loop instead of the "%PrepareFunctionForOptimization"/"%OptimizeFunctionOnNextCall" intrinsics.<!----></span><br><br>This primitive can also be used to introduce partially-known types: For example, `(o.c0 & 1)` can be typed to `Range(0, 1)` (and is later constant-folded into `0`).<span class="line"><!---->This primitive can also be used to introduce partially-known types: For example, `(o.c0 &amp; 1)` can be typed to `Range(0, 1)` (and is later constant-folded into `0`).<!----></span><br><br>Typer-transparent variables<span class="line"><!---->Typer-transparent variables<!----></span><br>---------------------------<span class="line"><!---->---------------------------<!----></span><br><br>Sometimes, the opposite construct is useful: a value whose type is fully known to the typer, but that isn't constant-folded away.<span class="line"><!---->Sometimes, the opposite construct is useful: a value whose type is fully known to the typer, but that isn't constant-folded away.<!----></span><br>This can be used to prevent unwanted optimizations, while maintaining type information that's as precise as possible.<span class="line"><!---->This can be used to prevent unwanted optimizations, while maintaining type information that's as precise as possible.<!----></span><br>To do this, speculative conversions can be abused to make the typer assume a certain branch being taken, which results in a constant type (this is not a bug in itself, as the speculative assumptions are appropriately guarded by checks).<span class="line"><!---->To do this, speculative conversions can be abused to make the typer assume a certain branch being taken, which results in a constant type (this is not a bug in itself, as the speculative assumptions are appropriately guarded by checks).<!----></span><br>The following construct seems to work well:<span class="line"><!---->The following construct seems to work well:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>    let c0a = arg_true ? 0 : "x";<span class="line"><!---->    let c0a = arg_true ? 0 : "x";<!----></span><br>    let c0 = Math.max(c0a, 0) + c0a;<span class="line"><!---->    let c0 = Math.max(c0a, 0) + c0a;<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>where `arg_true` is a function argument that is always set to `true` (giving `false` correctly leads to deoptimization).<span class="line"><!---->where `arg_true` is a function argument that is always set to `true` (giving `false` correctly leads to deoptimization).<!----></span><br>It somehow results in `c0` having Type `Range(0, 0)` without being constant-folded away.<span class="line"><!---->It somehow results in `c0` having Type `Range(0, 0)` without being constant-folded away.<!----></span><br>I did not investigate the exact reason for this construct having the desired effect.<span class="line"><!---->I did not investigate the exact reason for this construct having the desired effect.<!----></span><br><br>Breaking the Typer<span class="line"><!---->Breaking the Typer<!----></span><br>------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------<!----></span><br><br>There are still some obstacles in constructing a mis-typed value.<span class="line"><!---->There are still some obstacles in constructing a mis-typed value.<!----></span><br>First, let's look at `TryMatchWord32Ror` in some more detail:<span class="line"><!---->First, let's look at `TryMatchWord32Ror` in some more class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>It at first seems easiest to use the first case where both shift amounts are known constants, but there is a problem:<span class="line"><!---->It at first seems easiest to use the first case where both shift amounts are known constants, but there is a problem:<!----></span><br>If either of the shift amonuts is a zero constant, the shift will be completely optimized away.<span class="line"><!---->If either of the shift amonuts is a zero constant, the shift will be completely optimized away.<!----></span><br>We could instead use shift amounts like -32 and 64; however having both shift amounts outside the interval `[0, 31]` will unfortunately in the end lead to an unconstrained output type due to internals of the typer described below.<span class="line"><!---->We could instead use shift amounts like -32 and 64; however having both shift amounts outside the interval `[0, 31]` will unfortunately in the end lead to an unconstrained output type due to internals of the typer described below.<!----></span><br>Instead, we will use the described technique of "typer-transparent variables" and have one shift amount be equal to the constructed `c0` (which has type `Range(0,0)`), and the other one equal to `32-c0` (which has type `Range(32,32)`).<span class="line"><!---->Instead, we will use the described technique of "typer-transparent variables" and have one shift amount be equal to the constructed `c0` (which has type `Range(0,0)`), and the other one equal to `32-c0` (which has type `Range(32,32)`).<!----></span><br>Those expressions precisely match the second case, while also giving fully transparent information about their values to the typer, but also not enabling optimization of `x >> c0` to `x`.<span class="line"><!---->Those expressions precisely match the second case, while also giving fully transparent information about their values to the typer, but also not enabling optimization of `x &gt;&gt; c0` to `x`.<!----></span><br><br>Now, let's look at the relevant pieces of `operation-typer.cc` that are responsible for giving our initial expression its type:<span class="line"><!---->Now, let's look at the relevant pieces of `operation-typer.cc` that are responsible for giving our initial expression its type:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Type < 0 && rmax < 0)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if ((lmin &gt;= 0 &amp;&amp; rmin &gt;= 0) || (lmax &lt; 0 &amp;&amp; rmax &lt; 0)) {<!----></span><br>    // Xor-ing negative or non-negative values results in a non-negative value.<span class="line"><!---->    // Xor-ing negative or non-negative values results in a non-negative value.<!----></span><br>    return Type::Unsigned31();<span value.<span class="line"><!---->    // Xor-ing a negative and a non-negative value results in a negative value.<!----></span><br>    // TODO(jarin) Use a range here.<span class="line"><!---->    // TODO(jarin) Use a range here.<!----></span><br>    return Type::Negative32();<span class="line"><!---->    return Type::Negative32();<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>  return Type::Signed32();<span class="line"><!---->  return Type::Signed32();<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Unfortunately, this only computes sign information, so we need inputs where the optimization results in a value with the wrong sign bit.<span class="line"><!---->Unfortunately, this only computes sign information, so we need inputs where the optimization results in a value with the wrong sign bit.<!----></span><br>Here is the typer for left shifts (the one for logical right-shifts is quite similar, except for the overflow-check):<span class="line"><!---->Here is the typer for left shifts (the one for logical right-shifts is quite similar, except for the overflow-check):<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Type OperationTyper::NumberShiftLeft(Type lhs, Type rhs) {<span class="line"><!---->Type OperationTyper::NumberShiftLeft(Type lhs, Type rhs) {<!----></span><br>  ...<span class="line"><!---->  ...<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  lhs = NumberToInt32(lhs);<span class="line"><!---->  lhs = NumberToInt32(lhs);<!----></span><br>  rhs = NumberToUint32(rhs);<span class="line"><!---->  rhs = NumberToUint32(rhs);<!----></span><br><br>  ...<span class="line"><!---->  ...<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  if (max_rhs > 31) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (max_rhs &gt; 31) {<!----></span><br>    // rhs can be larger than the bitmask<span class="line"><!---->    // rhs can be larger than the bitmask<!----></span><br>    max_rhs = 31;<span class="line"><!---->    max_rhs = 31;<!----></span><br>    min_rhs = 0;<span class="line"><!---->    min_rhs = 0;<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br><br>  if (max_lhs > (kMaxInt >> max_rhs) || min_lhs < (kMinInt >> max_rhs)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (max_lhs &gt; (kMaxInt &gt;&gt; max_rhs) || min_lhs &lt; (kMinInt &gt;&gt; max_rhs)) {<!----></span><br>    // overflow possible<span class="line"><!---->    // overflow possible<!----></span><br>    return Type::Signed32();<span class="line"><!---->    return Type::Signed32();<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br><br>  double min =<span class="line"><!---->  double min =<!----></span><br>      std::min(static_cast<int32_t>(static_cast<uint32_t>(min_lhs) << min_rhs),<span class="line"><!---->      std::min(static_cast&lt;int32_t&gt;(static_cast&lt;uint32_t&gt;(min_lhs) &lt;&lt; min_rhs),<!----></span><br>               static_cast<int32_t>(static_cast<uint32_t>(min_lhs) << max_rhs));<span class="line"><!---->               static_cast&lt;int32_t&gt;(static_cast&lt;uint32_t&gt;(min_lhs) &lt;&lt; max_rhs));<!----></span><br>  double max =<span class="line"><!---->  double max =<!----></span><br>      std::max(static_cast<int32_t>(static_cast<uint32_t>(max_lhs) << min_rhs),<span class="line"><!---->      std::max(static_cast&lt;int32_t&gt;(static_cast&lt;uint32_t&gt;(max_lhs) &lt;&lt; min_rhs),<!----></span><br>               static_cast<int32_t>(static_cast<uint32_t>(max_lhs) << max_rhs));<span class="line"><!---->               static_cast&lt;int32_t&gt;(static_cast&lt;uint32_t&gt;(max_lhs) &lt;&lt; max_rhs));<!----></span><br><br>  if (max == kMaxInt && min == kMinInt) return Type::Signed32();<span class="line"><!---->  if (max == kMaxInt &amp;&amp; min == kMinInt) return Type::Signed32();<!----></span><br>  return Type::Range(min, max, zone());<span class="line"><!---->  return Type::Range(min, max, zone());<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Problematic is the check `max_rhs > 31`: If the shift amounts have to sum to 32, one of them has to lie outside the range `[0, 31]`, which makes it completely unknown to the typer.<span class="line"><!---->Problematic is the check `max_rhs &gt; 31`: If the shift amounts have to sum to 32, one of them has to lie outside the range `[0, 31]`, which makes it completely unknown to the typer.<!----></span><br>But there is one case that still works: consider `x=-1` and the expression `(x>>>0) ^ (x<<32)`.<span class="line"><!---->But there is one case that still works: consider `x=-1` and the expression `(x&gt;&gt;&gt;0) ^ (x&lt;&lt;32)`.<!----></span><br>The typer can easily reason the left side to be equal to `-1` and thus negative; and for the right side it considers all possible shifts from `x<<31` to `x<<0`, which are still all negative.<span class="line"><!---->The typer can easily reason the left side to be equal to `-1` and thus negative; and for the right side it considers all possible shifts from `x&lt;&lt;31` to `x&lt;&lt;0`, which are still all negative.<!----></span><br>Thus, both sides get typed to a range of negative 32-bit integers; which results in the xor-Result having type `Unsigned31`.<span class="line"><!---->Thus, both sides get typed to a range of negative 32-bit integers; which results in the xor-Result having type `Unsigned31`.<!----></span><br>However, after the faulty optimization the result is actually `ror(-1, 0) = -1`, which is negative, thus breaking the typer's range-tracking.<span class="line"><!---->However, after the faulty optimization the result is actually `ror(-1, 0) = -1`, which is negative, thus breaking the typer's range-tracking.<!----></span><br><br>There are two additional details:<span class="line"><!---->There are two additional details:<!----></span><br>First, because the logical right-shift works on unsigned 32-bit values, we have to supply the value `2**32-1` instead of `-1`, or else the typer's `NumberToUint32` operation couldn't reason about the result of the Uint32-truncation.<span class="line"><!---->First, because the logical right-shift works on unsigned 32-bit values, we have to supply the value `2**32-1` instead of `-1`, or else the typer's `NumberToUint32` operation couldn't reason about the result of the Uint32-truncation.<!----></span><br>Conversely, we have to subtract `2**32` from the result (which has type `Range(2**32-1, 2**32-1)` at this point) to actually bring it in the negative range (in the view of the typer).<span class="line"><!---->Conversely, we have to subtract `2**32` from the result (which has type `Range(2**32-1, 2**32-1)` at this point) to actually bring it in the negative range (in the view of the typer).<!----></span><br>This is not actually a problem: After the SimplifiedLowering-stage decides that all relevant values can be truncated to 32-bit words the constants `2**32-1` and `-1` get merged (thus passing the check of `TryMatchWord32Ror` that the left-hand sides of the shifts are the same node), and the subtraction gets truncated to a `Word32Sub(..., 0)`, which gets optimized away.<span class="line"><!---->This is not actually a problem: After the SimplifiedLowering-stage decides that all relevant values can be truncated to 32-bit words the constants `2**32-1` and `-1` get merged (thus passing the check of `TryMatchWord32Ror` that the left-hand sides of the shifts are the same node), and the subtraction gets truncated to a `Word32Sub(..., 0)`, which gets optimized away.<!----></span><br><br>Second, this new subtraction has the problem of getting constant-folded away; to prevent this, we can simply use the technique of "typer-opaque constants"; instead of subtracting `2**32` we subtract `2**32 + (o.c0&1)` which has type `Range(2**32, 2**32+1)`, but is known to be `2**32` after SimplifiedLowering.<span class="line"><!---->Second, this new subtraction has the problem of getting constant-folded away; to prevent this, we can simply use the technique of "typer-opaque constants"; instead of subtracting `2**32` we subtract `2**32 + (o.c0&amp;1)` which has type `Range(2**32, 2**32+1)`, but is known to be `2**32` after SimplifiedLowering.<!----></span><br>This just widens the left-hand side's type to `Range(-2, -1)`, still maintaining the information that it is negative.<span class="line"><!---->This just widens the left-hand side's type to `Range(-2, -1)`, still maintaining the information that it is negative.<!----></span><br><br>To make that wrongly-typed value a bit nicer we finally (arithmetically) right-shift by `31`, resulting in a type of `Range(0,0)` but a real value of `-1`.<span class="line"><!---->To make that wrongly-typed value a bit nicer we finally (arithmetically) right-shift by `31`, resulting in a type of `Range(0,0)` but a real value of `-1`.<!----></span><br><br>The full PoC for breaking the typer is:<span class="line"><!---->The full PoC for breaking the typer is:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>function foo(arg_true) {<span class="line"><!---->function foo(arg_true) {<!----></span><br>    let o = {c0: 0};<span class="line"><!---->    let o = {c0: 0};<!----></span><br>    let c0a = arg_true ? 0 : "x";<span class="line"><!---->    let c0a = arg_true ? 0 : "x";<!----></span><br>    let c0 = (Math.max(c0a, 0) + c0a);<span class="line"><!---->    let c0 = (Math.max(c0a, 0) + c0a);<!----></span><br>    let v01 = 2**32 + (o.c0 & 1);<span class="line"><!---->    let v01 = 2**32 + (o.c0 &amp; 1);<!----></span><br>    let ra = ((2**32-1) >>> c0) - v01;<span class="line"><!---->    let ra = ((2**32-1) &gt;&gt;&gt; c0) - v01;<!----></span><br>    let rb = ((-1) << (32-c0));<span class="line"><!---->    let rb = ((-1) &lt;&lt; (32-c0));<!----></span><br>    return (ra^rb) >> 31;<span class="line"><!---->    return (ra^rb) &gt;&gt; 31;<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>for (var i = 0; i < 3e4; i++) foo(true);<span class="line"><!---->for (var i = 0; i &lt; 3e4; i++) foo(true);<!----></span><br>console.log(foo(true));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(foo(true));<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>The resulting output is `-1`, while the the type of the final `SpeculativeNumberShiftRight` node is `Range(0, 0)`.<span class="line"><!---->The resulting output is `-1`, while the the type of the final `SpeculativeNumberShiftRight` node is `Range(0, 0)`.<!----></span><br><br><br>Typer hardening bypass<span class="line"><!---->Typer hardening bypass<!----></span><br>----------------------<span class="line"><!---->----------------------<!----></span><br><br>I additionally found a new typer hardening bypass to escalate this bug into arbitrary code execution.<span class="line"><!---->I additionally found a new typer hardening bypass to escalate this bug into arbitrary code execution.<!----></span><br>Array accesses should all be guarded by appropriate `CheckBounds` nodes to prevent out-of-bound-accesses in case of typer bugs.<span class="line"><!---->Array accesses should all be guarded by appropriate `CheckBounds` nodes to prevent out-of-bound-accesses in case of typer bugs.<!----></span><br>However, this is not the case when accesssing an array via an iterator.<span class="line"><!---->However, this is not the case when accesssing an array via an iterator.<!----></span><br>Consider `JSCallReducer::ReduceArrayIteratorPrototypeNext` in `src/compiler/js-call-reducer.cc`; the only two index-checks performed are the following (around line 6250): <span class="line"><!---->Consider `JSCallReducer::ReduceArrayIteratorPrototypeNext` in `src/compiler/js-call-reducer.cc`; the only two index-checks performed are the following (around line 6250): <!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>  Node* check = graph()->NewNode(simplified()->NumberLessThan(), index, length);<span class="line"><!---->  Node* check = graph()-&gt;NewNode(simplified()-&gt;NumberLessThan(), index, length);<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  ...<span class="line"><!---->  ...<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>    index = etrue = graph()->NewNode(<span class="line"><!---->    index = etrue = graph()-&gt;NewNode(<!----></span><br>        common()->TypeGuard(<span class="line"><!---->        common()-&gt;TypeGuard(<!----></span><br>            Type::Range(0.0, length_access.type.Max() - 1.0, graph()->zone())),<span class="line"><!---->            Type::Range(0.0, length_access.type.Max() - 1.0, graph()-&gt;zone())),<!----></span><br>        index, etrue, if_true);<span class="line"><!---->        index, etrue, if_true);<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>However, this is not enough: Due to the LoadElimination stage, the length of the array can actually be propagated directly from the value we give into the array constructor, which means that type information is also propagated.<span class="line"><!---->However, this is not enough: Due to the LoadElimination stage, the length of the array can actually be propagated directly from the value we give into the array constructor, which means that type information is also propagated.<!----></span><br>This can result in the elimination of the `NumberLessThan()`-check, leading to an out-of-bounds-access.<span class="line"><!---->This can result in the elimination of the `NumberLessThan()`-check, leading to an out-of-bounds-access.<!----></span><br><br>Thus, we can simply construct an array with a length shorter than its type implies, construct an iterator and incrementally push it out-of-bounds with repeated `next()`-calls (for this we can't use a loop, as the type-constraints for the current index position have to propagate from each call to the next).<span class="line"><!---->Thus, we can simply construct an array with a length shorter than its type implies, construct an iterator and incrementally push it out-of-bounds with repeated `next()`-calls (for this we can't use a loop, as the type-constraints for the current index position have to propagate from each call to the next).<!----></span><br>From there, read-write-access can be obtained into an adjacent array of a different type, which enables getting object addresses and constructing fake objects.<span class="line"><!---->From there, read-write-access can be obtained into an adjacent array of a different type, which enables getting object addresses and constructing fake objects.<!----></span><br>Then, well-known techniques can be used to obtain arbtirary read+write, get a rwx page using web assembly, and execute shellcode (for details see `ror_rce.js`).<span class="line"><!---->Then, well-known techniques can be used to obtain arbtirary read+write, get a rwx page using web assembly, and execute shellcode (for details see `ror_rce.js`).<!----></span><br><br>Fixing the bypass<span class="line"><!---->Fixing the bypass<!----></span><br>-----------------<span class="line"><!---->-----------------<!----></span><br><br>To fix the bypass, the `TypeGuard()` could simply be replaced by a proper `CheckBounds()`-node.<span class="line"><!---->To fix the bypass, the `TypeGuard()` could simply be replaced by a proper `CheckBounds()`-node.<!----></span><br>A suggested patch is attached as `js-call-reducer.cc.patch`.<span class="line"><!---->A suggested patch is attached as `js-call-reducer.cc.patch`.<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please briefly explain who can exploit the vulnerability, and what they gain when doing so<span class="line"><!---->#### Please briefly explain who can exploit the vulnerability, and what they gain when doing so<!----></span><br><br>An attacker running a malicious website can get arbitrary code-execution in the context of Chrome's renderer process.<span class="line"><!---->An attacker running a malicious website can get arbitrary code-execution in the context of Chrome's renderer process.<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The cause<span class="line"><!---->### The cause<!----></span><br><br><br>#### What version of Chrome have you found the security issue in?<span class="line"><!---->#### What version of Chrome have you found the security issue in?<!----></span><br><br>Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux; current main branch of v8<span class="line"><!---->Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux; current main branch of v8<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Is the security issue related to a crash?<span class="line"><!---->#### Is the security issue related to a crash?<!----></span><br><br>No<span class="line"><!---->No<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Choose the type of vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Choose the type of vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Remote Code Execution (RCE)<span class="line"><!---->Remote Code Execution (RCE)<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please provide your credit information<span class="line"><!---->#### Please provide your credit information<!----></span><br><br>Manfred Paul (@_manfp)<span class="line"><!---->Manfred Paul         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion.            issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>

        for LitElement.

          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;

          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);

  :host {
    --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
    --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
    --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
    color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /** Converts a <button> to look like an <a> tag. */
  .linkify {
    display: inline;
    padding: 0;
    margin: 0;
    border: 0;
    background: 0;
    cursor: pointer;
  }
  h1, h2, h3, h4 {
    background: none;
  }
  a, chops-button, a.button, .button, .linkify {
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    text-decoration: none;
    font-weight: var(--chops-link-font-weight);
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
  }
  a:hover, .linkify:hover {
    text-decoration: underline;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    /* Links that look like buttons. */
    display: inline-flex;
    align-items: center;
    justify-content: center;
    text-decoration: none;
    transition: filter 0.3s ease-in-out, box-shadow 0.3s ease-in-out;
  }
  a.button:hover, .button:hover {
    filter: brightness(95%);
  }
  chops-button, a.button, .button {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
    background: var(--chops-white);
    border-radius: 6px;
    --chops-button-padding: 0.25em 8px;
    margin: 0;
    margin-left: auto;
  }

    padding: var(--chops-button-padding);
  }

    display: block;
    margin-right: 4px;
  }
  chops-button.emphasized, a.button.emphasized, .button.emphasized {
    background: var(--chops-primary-button-bg);
    color: var(--chops-primary-button-color);
    text-shadow: 1px 1px 3px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.25);
  }
  textarea, select, input {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /* Note: decoupling heading levels from styles is useful for
  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically
  * appropriate heading levels.
  */
  .medium-heading {
    font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
    font-weight: normal;
    line-height: 1;
    padding: 0.25em 0;
    color: var(--chops-link-color);

    border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);

  }

    padding: 0.5em 0;
    display: grid;
    max-width: 100%;
    grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
    grid-template-columns: minmax(120px, max-content) 1fr;
    align-items: flex-start;
  }
  .input-grid label {
    font-weight: bold;
    text-align: right;
    word-wrap: break-word;
  }

    .input-grid label {
      margin-top: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      text-align: left;
    }
    .input-grid {
      grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      grid-template-columns: 100%;
    }

          position: fixed;
          bottom: 1em;
          left: 1em;
          display: flex;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: flex-start;
          z-index: 1000;
        }
        /** Unfix <chops-snackbar> to allow stacking. */
        chops-snackbar {
          position: static;
          margin-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .project-alert {
          background: var(--chops-orange-50);
          color: var(--chops-field-error-color);
          display: block;
          font-weight: bold;
          text-align: center;
        }
      <style>
        
  :host {
    --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
    --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
    --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
    color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /** Converts a <button> to look like an <a> tag. */
  .linkify {
    display: inline;
    padding: 0;
    margin: 0;
    border: 0;
    background: 0;
    cursor: pointer;
  }
  h1, h2, h3, h4 {
    background: none;
  }
  a, chops-button, a.button, .button, .linkify {
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    text-decoration: none;
    font-weight: var(--chops-link-font-weight);
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
  }
  a:hover, .linkify:hover {
    text-decoration: underline;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    /* Links that look like buttons. */
    display: inline-flex;
    align-items: center;
    justify-content: center;
    text-decoration: none;
    transition: filter 0.3s ease-in-out, box-shadow 0.3s ease-in-out;
  }
  a.button:hover, .button:hover {
    filter: brightness(95%);
  }
  chops-button, a.button, .button {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
    background: var(--chops-white);
    border-radius: 6px;
    --chops-button-padding: 0.25em 8px;
    margin: 0;
    margin-left: auto;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    padding: var(--chops-button-padding);
  }
  chops-button i.material-icons, a.button i.material-icons, .button i.material-icons {
    display: block;
    margin-right: 4px;
  }
  chops-button.emphasized, a.button.emphasized, .button.emphasized {
    background: var(--chops-primary-button-bg);
    color: var(--chops-primary-button-color);
    text-shadow: 1px 1px 3px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.25);
  }
  textarea, select, input {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /* Note: decoupling heading levels from styles is useful for
  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically
  * appropriate heading levels.
  */
  .medium-heading {
    font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
    font-weight: normal;
    line-height: 1;
    padding: 0.25em 0;
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    margin: 0;
    margin-top: 0.25em;
    border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
  }
  .medium-heading chops-button {
    line-height: 1.6;
  }
  .input-grid {
    padding: 0.5em 0;
    display: grid;
    max-width: 100%;
    grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
    grid-template-columns: minmax(120px, max-content) 1fr;
    align-items: flex-start;
  }
  .input-grid label {
    font-weight: bold;
    text-align: right;
    word-wrap: break-word;
  }
  @media (max-width: 600px) {
    .input-grid label {
      margin-top: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      text-align: left;
    }
    .input-grid {
      grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      grid-template-columns: 100%;
    }
  }

        mr-app {
          display: block;
          padding-top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-top: -1px; /* Prevent a double border from showing up. */

          /* From shared-styles.js. */
          --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
          --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
          --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
          font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
          color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
        }
        main {
          border-top: var(--chops-normal-border);
        }
        .snackbar-container {
          position: fixed;
          bottom: 1em;
          left: 1em;
          display: flex;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: flex-start;
          z-index: 1000;
        }
        /** Unfix <chops-snackbar> to allow stacking. */
        chops-snackbar {
          position: static;
          margin-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .project-alert {
          background: var(--chops-orange-50);
          color: var(--chops-field-error-color);
          display: block;
          font-weight: bold;
          text-align: center;
        }

          Note: Only signed in users can star issues or add comments, and
          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.

          Note: Only signed in users can star issues or add comments, and
          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.

          <!---->

              <span></span><span class="help-title"><!---->Anywhere<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->/<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->focus on the issue search field<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->c<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->compose a new issue<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->s<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->star the current issue<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->?<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->show this help dialog<!----></span>
              <!---->
            </div>
          <!---->
        </div>
        <p>
          Note: Only signed in users can star issues or add comments, and
          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.
        </p>
      </chops-dialog>
    <mr-keystrokes></mr-keystrokes>

          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

      ---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Report description<span class="line"><!---->### Report description<!----></span><br><br><br>v8/Turbofan: Invalid rotate-right optimization + Typer hardening bypass<span class="line"><!---->v8/Turbofan: Invalid rotate-right optimization + Typer hardening bypass<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Bug location<span class="line"><!---->### Bug location<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<span class="line"><!---->#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<!----></span><br><br>Google Chrome<span class="line"><!---->Google Chrome<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The problem<span class="line"><!---->### The problem<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Tested on:<span class="line"><!---->Tested on:<!----></span><br>==========<span class="line"><!---->==========<!----></span><br><br> - Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux (other platforms affected too)<span class="line"><!----> - Chromium 92.0.4515.107 Arch Linux (other platforms affected too)<!----></span><br> - v8/d8 on current main branch on Linux<span class="line"><!----> - v8/d8 on current main branch on Linux<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br>Test case:<span class="line"><!---->Test case:<!----></span><br>==========<span class="line"><!---->==========<!----></span><br><br>Execute the following snippet in Chrome's Javascript console or d8:<span class="line"><!---->Execute the following snippet in Chrome's Javascript console or d8:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>function foo(a,b) {<span class="line"><!---->function foo(a,b) {<!----></span><br>    a = a|0;<span class="line"><!---->    a = a|0;<!----></span><br>    b = b|0;<span class="line"><!---->    b = b|0;<!----></span><br>    return (a >>> b) ^ (a << (32-b));<span class="line"><!---->    return (a &gt;&gt;&gt; b) ^ (a &lt;&lt; (32-b));<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>console.log(foo(1, 0));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(foo(1, 0));<!----></span><br>for (var i = 0; i < 3e5; i++) foo(1, 0);<span class="line"><!---->for (var i = 0; i &lt; 3e5; i++) foo(1, 0);<!----></span><br>console.log(foo(1, 0));<span class="line"><!---->console.log(foo(1, 0));<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>The expected behavior would be to print "0" twice; instead "0" and "1" are printed.<span class="line"><!---->The expected behavior would be to print "0" twice; instead "0" and "1" are printed.<!----></span><br>I will show below how this can be used to construct mis-typed values, and achieve arbitrary code execution in the context of v8/Chrome's Renderer process using a typer hardening bypass.<span class="line"><!---->I will show below how this can be used to construct mis-typed values, and achieve arbitrary code execution in the context of v8/Chrome's Renderer process using a typer hardening bypass.<!----></span><br><br><br>Root Cause:<span class="line"><!---->Root Cause:<!----></span><br>===========<span class="line"><!---->===========<!----></span><br><br>The relevant optimization is `MachineOperatorReducer::TryMatchWord32Ror()`, around line 1838 of v8's `src/compiler/machine-operator-reducer.cc`:<span class="line"><!---->The relevant optimization is `MachineOperatorReducer::TryMatchWord32Ror()`, around line 1838 of v8's `src/compiler/machine-operator-reducer.cc`:<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Reduction MachineOperatorReducer::TryMatchWord32Ror(Node* node) {<span class="line"><!---->Reduction MachineOperatorReducer::TryMatchWord32Ror(Node* node) {<!----></span><br>  DCHECK(IrOpcode::kWord32Or == node->opcode() ||<span class="line"><!---->  DCHECK(IrOpcode::kWord32Or == node-&gt;opcode() ||<!----></span><br>         IrOpcode::kWord32Xor == node->opcode());<span class="line"><!---->         IrOpcode::kWord32Xor == node-&gt;opcode());<!----></span><br>  Int32BinopMatcher m(node);<span class="line"><!---->  Int32BinopMatcher m(node);<!----></span><br>  Node* shl = nullptr;<span class="line"><!---->  Node* shl = nullptr;<!----></span><br>  Node* shr = nullptr;<span class="line"><!---->  Node* shr = nullptr;<!----></span><br>  // Recognize rotation, we are matching:<span class="line"><!---->  // Recognize rotation, we are matching:<!----></span><br>  //  * x << y | x >>> (32 - y) => x ror (32 - y), i.e  x rol y<span class="line"><!---->  //  * x &lt;&lt; y | x &gt;&gt;&gt; (32 - y) =&gt; x ror (32 - y), i.e  x rol y<!----></span><br>  //  * x << (32 - y) | x >>> y => x ror y<span class="line"><!---->  //  * x &lt;&lt; (32 - y) | x &gt;&gt;&gt; y =&gt; x ror y<!----></span><br>  //  * x << y ^ x >>> (32 - y) => x ror (32 - y), i.e. x rol y<span class="line"><!---->  //  * x &lt;&lt; y ^ x &gt;&gt;&gt; (32 - y) =&gt; x ror (32 - y), i.e. x rol y<!----></span><br>  //  * x << (32 - y) ^ x >>> y => x ror y<span class="line"><!---->  //  * x &lt;&lt; (32 - y) ^ x &gt;&gt;&gt; y =&gt; x ror y<!----></span><br>  // as well as their commuted form.<span class="line"><!---->  // as well as their commuted form.<!----></span><br>  ...<span class="line"><!---->  ...<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>Consider the last two reductions with the case `y = 0` (or more generally, `y` divisible by 32).<span class="line"><!---->Consider the last two reductions with the case `y = 0` (or more generally, `y` divisible by 32).<!----></span><br>In this case, both left and right shift are by an amount divisible by 32; but as shift amounts are truncated to their last 5 bits this is equivalent to no shift occuring at all, so the left-hand side actually reduces to `x ^ x = 0`.<span class="line"><!---->In this case, both left and right shift are by an amount divisible by 32; but as shift amounts are truncated to their last 5 bits this is equivalent to no shift occuring at all, so the left-hand side actually reduces to `x ^ x = 0`.<!----></span><br>However, the right-hand side reduces to `x ror 0 = x` (again, rotation amounts divisible by 32 are equivalent to 0), which is wrong for non-zero values of `x`.<span class="line"><!---->However, the right-hand side reduces to `x ror 0 = x` (again, rotation amounts divisible by 32 are equivalent to 0), which is wrong for non-zero values of `x`.<!----></span><br><br>Fix:<span class="line"><!---->Fix:<!----></span><br>====<span class="line"><!---->====<!----></span><br><br>The easiest fix would be to disallow the reduction for the Word32Xor operator.<span class="line"><!---->The easiest fix would be to disallow the reduction for the Word32Xor operator.<!----></span><br>However, the optimization can still be performed for the case where `y` and `32 - y` are constants and known to be non-zero (modulo 32).<span class="line"><!---->However, the optimization can still be performed for the case where `y` and `32 - y` are constants and known to be non-zero (modulo 32).<!----></span><br>It's of course enough to check this for `y`.<span class="line"><!---->It's of course enough to check this for `y`.<!----></span><br>A suggested patch is attached as `machine-operator-reducer.cc.patch`.<span class="line"><!---->A suggested patch is attached as `machine-operator-reducer.cc.patch`.<!----></span><br>Optimizing the case of y being constant 0 to `0` does not seem to make sense, as this should already be handled by the existing reductions for shifts and xor.<span class="line"><!---->Optimizing the case of y being constant 0 to `0` does not seem to make sense, as this should already be handled by the existing reductions for shifts and xor.<!----></span><br><br>Note also that the Word32Or-case is unaffected by the bug, as `x << 0 | x >>> 32` is equal to `x | x = x`, which matches `ror(x, 0)`.<span class="line"><!---->Note also that the Word32Or-case is unaffected by the bug, as `x &lt;&lt; 0 | x &gt;&gt;&gt; 32` is equal to `x | x = x`, which matches `ror(x, 0)`.<!----></span><br><br>Exploiting the bug:<span class="line"><!---->Exploiting the bug:<!----></span><br>===================<span class="line"><!---->===================<!----></span><br><br>The rest of this write-up will describe how exactly the bug was triggered in a way that causes a type confusion, and how this type confusion can be leveraged into arbitrary code exeuction using a new typer-hardening bypass.<span class="line"><!---->The rest of this write-up will describe how exactly the bug was triggered in a way that causes a type confusion, and how this type confusion can be leveraged into arbitrary code exeuction using a new typer-hardening bypass.<!----></span><br>A full exploit that executes a customizable shellcode (in the example, for Linux x64) is attached as `ror_rce.js`.<span class="line"><!---->A full exploit that executes a customizable shellcode (in the example, for Linux x64) is attached as `ror_rce.js`.<!----></span><br>It can either be run with a current version of `d8` or embedded into a html file openened with `chrome --no-sandbox` (however the example shellcode has no observable effect when run in Chrome's renderer; there doesn't seem to be an easy portable way to pop a calc on Linux :( ).<span class="line"><!---->It can either be run with a current version of `d8` or embedded into a html file openened with `chrome --no-sandbox` (however class="line"><!---->----------------------<!----></span><br><br>It is useful to have values that are unknown to the Typer-phase, but that can be fully reduced to constants during later phases like EarlyOptimization, where `MachineOperatorReducer` is first run.<span class="line"><!---->It is useful to have values that are unknown to the Typer-phase, but that can be fully reduced to constants during later phases like EarlyOptimization, where `MachineOperatorReducer` is first run.<!----></span><br>This can be used to introduce uncertainty into types where needed to prevent e.g. constant folding.<span class="line"><!---->This can be used to introduce uncertainty into types where needed to prevent e.g. constant folding.<!----></span><br>This primitive can be obtained using the LoadElimination-phase: We use a local object `o` to hold a constant `c0` equal to zero; whenever we load this constant the typer can speculate that this is a number, but cannot reason about its exact value.<span class="line"><!---->This primitive can be obtained using the LoadElimination-phase: We use a local object `o` to hold a constant `c0` equal to zero; whenever we load this constant the typer can speculate that this is a number, but cannot reason about its exact value.<!----></span><br><br>During LoadElimination, this is replaced by a constant `0` node, enabling further optimizations.<span class="line"><!---->During LoadElimination, this is replaced by a constant `0` node, enabling further optimizations.<!----></span><br>Note: For unknown reasons, the LoadElimination only seems to work properly when causing the function's optimization with a loop instead of the "%PrepareFunctionForOptimization"/"%OptimizeFunctionOnNextCall" intrinsics.<span class="line"><!---->Note: For unknown reasons, the LoadElimination only seems to work properly when causing the function's optimization with a loop instead of the "%PrepareFunctionForOptimization"/"%OptimizeFunctionOnNextCall" intrinsics.<!----></span><br><br>This primitive can also be used to introduce partially-known types: For example, `(o.c0 & 1)` can be to `Range(0, 1)` (and is later constant-folded into `0`).<!----></span><br><br>Typer-transparent variables<span class="line"><!---->Typer-transparent seems easiest to use the first case where both shift amounts are known constants, but there is a problem:<!----></span><br>If either of the shift amonuts is a zero constant, the shift will be completely optimized away.<span class="line"><!---->If either of the shift amonuts is a zero constant, the shift will be completely optimized away.<!----></span><br>We could instead use shift amounts like -32 and 64; however having both shift amounts outside the interval `[0, 31]` will unfortunately in the end lead to an unconstrained output type due to internals of the typer described below.<span type due to internals of the typer described below.<!----></span><br>Instead, we will use the described technique of "typer-transparent variables" and have one shift amount be equal to the constructed `c0` (which has type `Range(0,0)`), and the other one equal to `32-c0` (which has type `Range(32,32)`).<span class="line"><!---->Instead, we will use the described technique of "typer-transparent variables" and have one shift amount be equal to the constructed `c0` (which has type `Range(0,0)`), and the other one equal to `32-c0` (which has type `Range(32,32)`).<!----></span><br>Those expressions precisely match the second case, while also giving fully transparent information about their values to the typer, but also not enabling optimization of `x >> c0` to `x`.<span
